{{Infobox web browser | name = Erwise | logo = | screenshot = [[File:Erwise5.jpg|180px]] | caption = Screenshot of the browser | author = | developer = [[Kim Nyberg]], [[Teemu Rantanen]], [[Kati Suominen]], [[Kari SydÃ¤nmaanlakka]]<ref name="neww3c">{{Cite web|title=World Wide Web People - "Erwise" team|url=http://www.w3.org/People.html#9|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=15 June 2010|author=[[Henrik Frystyk Nielsen]]|date=26 October 1999}}</ref> | released = 0.1 | latest release version = | latest release date = {{release date and age|1994|04|25}} | operating system = | platform = [[Unix]]([[Sun-4]],<ref name="comparison">{{Cite web|title=Comparison with ViolaWWW|url=http://www.w3.org/History/19921103-hypertext/hypertext/Erwise/Review.html|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=15 June 2010|author=[[Tim Berners-Lee]]|date=29 April 1992}}</ref> [[NeXT]]/[[CubX]],<ref name="comparison" /> [[Digital Equipment Corporation|DEC]]<ref name="comparison" /> [[Ultrix]]) over the [[Motif (widget toolkit)|motif]]<ref name="neww3c" /> | language = English | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]] | genre = [[web browser]] | license = [[Public Domain]] | discontinued = yes | website = }} '''Erwise''' was a pioneering [[web browser]], and the first commonly available with a [[graphical user interface]].<ref name="osnews">{{Cite web|last=Holwerda|first=Thom|title=The World's First Graphical Browser: Erwise|url=http://www.osnews.com/story/21076/The_World_s_First_Graphical_Browser_Erwise|publisher=[[OSNews]]|accessdate=15 June 2010|date=3 March 2009}}</ref><ref>http://cnlart.web.cern.ch/cnlart/2001/001/www-history/</ref>
Released in April 1992, the browser was written for [[Unix]] computers running [[X Window System|X]] and used the [[Libwww|W3 common access library]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Computing at CERN in the 1990s|url=http://cerncourier.com/cws/article/cnl/25822|publisher=[[cerncourier]]|accessdate=15 June 2010|date=7 September 2006}}</ref> Erwise was the combined master's project of four [[Finland|Finnish]] students at the [[Helsinki University of Technology]]:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.w3.org/People/Berners-Lee/FAQ.html#browser|title=What were the first WWW browsers?|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|author=[[Tim Berners-Lee]]|accessdate=2010-06-15}}</ref> Kim Nyberg, Teemu Rantanen, Kati Suominen and Kari SydÃ¤nmaanlakka.<ref name="neww3c" /><ref name="comparison" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xconomy.com/national/2009/03/03/the-greatest-internet-pioneers-you-never-heard-of-the-story-of-erwise-and-four-finns-who-showed-the-way-to-the-web-browser/ |title=The Greatest Internet Pioneers You Never Heard Of |publisher=Xconomy.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-15}}</ref> The group decided to create a web browser at the suggestion of [[Robert Cailliau]], who was visiting the university,<ref name="living">{{Cite web|first=Bill|last=Stewart|title=Web Browser History|url=http://www.livinginternet.com/w/wi_browse.htm|publisher=Living Internet|accessdate=15 June 2010}}</ref> and were supervised by [[Ari Lemmke]].
The development of Erwise halted after the students graduated and went on to other projects.<ref name="comparison" /> [[Tim Berners-Lee]], the creator of the [[World Wide Web]], travelled to Finland to encourage the group to continue with the project. However, none of the project members could afford to continue with the project without proper funding.<ref name="comparison" />
The name ''Erwise'' originates from ''otherwise'' and the name of the project group, ''OHT'', which is short for ''ohjelmatyÃ¶ryhmÃ¤'' (program working group).<ref name="living" /><ref name="status">{{Cite web|title=Status of "Erwise" browser|url=http://www.w3.org/History/19921103-hypertext/hypertext/WWW/Erwise/Status.html|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=15 June 2010}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.hs.fi/klik/arkisto/2000helmikuu/20000210klik99erwise.html |title=Helsingin Sanomat|date=10 February 2000|accessdate=2010-06-15|language=Finnish}}</ref> <!-- ==History== *Extremely pre-documented (in Finish).<ref name="status" /> *Serious coding started around March 1992.<ref name="status" /> *Alpha release available by anonymous FTP from info.cern.ch -- binaries only (sun4 works, decstation too, display requires motif) as of 15 April 1992.<ref name="status" /> *Source code released on www-talk August 92.<ref name="status" /> -->
==Characteristics== The following are significant characteristics of the browser: *It used a multifont text.<ref name="comparison" /> *The links of Erwise browser were underlined. To visit the links you had to double click on the links.<ref name="comparison" /> *Erwise could execute multiple window operation, though the optional single window mode was also available. *Erwise could open local files.<ref name="comparison" /> *Erwise had little English documentation. *Some of the buttons were for features that were not implemented. *Tim Berners-Lee would have continued with the works of Erwise. He could not do so because Erwise was documented in the Finnish language.<ref name="osnews" />
==Criticism== Erwise crashed on some [[Unices]], which Berners-Lee attributed to poor Motif implementations.<ref name="comparison" /><ref>{{Cite web|title=Viola and Erwise|url=http://www.w3.org/History/19921103-hypertext/hypertext/Erwise/vsViola.html|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=15 June 2010|author=[[Tim Berners-Lee]]}}</ref>
